AlarmHistoryItem.name: AlarmHistoryItem
AlarmHistoryItem.description: The AlarmHistoryItem data type contains descriptive information about the history of a specific alarm. If you call DescribeAlarmHistory, Amazon CloudWatch returns this data type as part of the DescribeAlarmHistoryResult data type.

Timestamp.name: Timestamp
Timestamp.description: The time stamp for the alarm history item.

HistorySummary.name: HistorySummary
HistorySummary.description: A human-readable summary of the alarm history.

HistoryData.name: HistoryData
HistoryData.description: Machine-readable data about the alarm in JSON format.

Datapoint.name: Datapoint
Datapoint.description: The Datapoint data type encapsulates the statistical data that Amazon CloudWatch computes from metric data.

Timestamp.name: Timestamp
Timestamp.description: The time stamp used for the datapoint.

SampleCount.name: SampleCount
SampleCount.description: The number of metric values that contributed to the aggregate value of this datapoint.

Average.name: Average
Average.description: The average of metric values that correspond to the datapoint.

Sum.name: Sum
Sum.description: The sum of metric values used for the datapoint.

Minimum.name: Minimum
Minimum.description: The minimum metric value used for the datapoint.

Maximum.name: Maximum
Maximum.description: The maximum of the metric value used for the datapoint.

Unit.name: Unit
Unit.description: The standard unit used for the datapoint.

AlarmNames.name: AlarmNames
AlarmNames.description: A list of alarms to be deleted.

HistoryItemType.name: HistoryItemType
HistoryItemType.description: The type of alarm histories to retrieve.

StartDate.name: StartDate
StartDate.description: The starting date to retrieve alarm history.

EndDate.name: EndDate
EndDate.description: The ending date to retrieve alarm history.

MaxRecords.name: MaxRecords
MaxRecords.description: The maximum number of alarm history records to retrieve.

NextToken.name: NextToken
NextToken.description: The token returned by a previous call to indicate that there is more data available.

AlarmHistoryItems.name: AlarmHistoryItems
AlarmHistoryItems.description: A list of alarm histories in JSON format.

NextToken.name: NextToken
NextToken.description: A string that marks the start of the next batch of returned results.

Dimensions.name: Dimensions
Dimensions.description: The list of dimensions associated with the metric. If the metric has any associated dimensions, you must specify them in order for the DescribeAlarmsForMetric to succeed.

Period.name: Period
Period.description: The period in seconds over which the statistic is applied.

MetricAlarms.name: MetricAlarms
MetricAlarms.description: A list of information for each alarm with the specified metric.

AlarmNames.name: AlarmNames
AlarmNames.description: A list of alarm names to retrieve information for.

AlarmNamePrefix.name: AlarmNamePrefix
AlarmNamePrefix.description: The alarm name prefix. AlarmNames cannot be specified if this parameter is specified.

StateValue.name: StateValue
StateValue.description: The state value to be used in matching alarms.

MaxRecords.name: MaxRecords
MaxRecords.description: The maximum number of alarm descriptions to retrieve.

NextToken.name: NextToken
NextToken.description: The token returned by a previous call to indicate that there is more data available.

MetricAlarms.name: MetricAlarms
MetricAlarms.description: A list of information for the specified alarms.

NextToken.name: NextToken
NextToken.description: A string that marks the start of the next batch of returned results.

Dimension.name: Dimension
Dimension.description:
The Dimension data type further expands on the identity of a metric using a Name, Value pair.

For examples that use one or more dimensions, see PutMetricData.

DimensionFilter.name: DimensionFilter
DimensionFilter.description: The DimensionFilter data type is used to filter ListMetrics results.

Value.name: Value
Value.description:
The value of the dimension to be matched.

Specifying a Name without specifying a Value returns all values associated with that Name.

AlarmNames.name: AlarmNames
AlarmNames.description: The names of the alarms to disable actions for.

AlarmNames.name: AlarmNames
AlarmNames.description: The names of the alarms to enable actions for.

Namespace.name: Namespace
Namespace.description: The namespace of the metric, with or without spaces.

MetricName.name: MetricName
MetricName.description: The name of the metric, with or without spaces.

Dimensions.name: Dimensions
Dimensions.description: A list of dimensions describing qualities of the metric.

StartTime.name: StartTime
StartTime.description:
The time stamp to use for determining the first datapoint to return. The value specified is inclusive; results include datapoints with the time stamp specified. The time stamp must be in ISO 8601 UTC format (e.g., 2014-09-03T23:00:00Z).

The specified start time is rounded down to the nearest value. Datapoints are returned for start times up to two weeks in the past. Specified start times that are more than two weeks in the past will not return datapoints for metrics that are older than two weeks.

Data that is timestamped 24 hours or more in the past may take in excess of 48 hours to become available from submission time using GetMetricStatistics.

EndTime.name: EndTime
EndTime.description: The time stamp to use for determining the last datapoint to return. The value specified is exclusive; results will include datapoints up to the time stamp specified. The time stamp must be in ISO 8601 UTC format (e.g., 2014-09-03T23:00:00Z).

Period.name: Period
Period.description: The granularity, in seconds, of the returned datapoints. A Period can be as short as one minute (60 seconds) or as long as one day (86,400 seconds), and must be a multiple of 60. The default value is 60.

Statistics.name: Statistics
Statistics.description: The metric statistics to return. For information about specific statistics returned by GetMetricStatistics, see Statistics in the Amazon CloudWatch Developer Guide.

Unit.name: Unit
Unit.description: The specific unit for a given metric. Metrics may be reported in multiple units. Not supplying a unit results in all units being returned. If the metric only ever reports one unit, specifying a unit will have no effect.

MetricName.name: MetricName
MetricName.description: The name of the metric to filter against.

Dimensions.name: Dimensions
Dimensions.description: A list of dimensions to filter against.

NextToken.name: NextToken
NextToken.description: The token returned by a previous call to indicate that there is more data available.

Metrics.name: Metrics
Metrics.description: A list of metrics used to generate statistics for an AWS account.

NextToken.name: NextToken
NextToken.description: A string that marks the start of the next batch of returned results.

Metric.name: Metric
Metric.description:
The Metric data type contains information about a specific metric. If you call ListMetrics, Amazon CloudWatch returns information contained by this data type.

The example in the Examples section publishes two metrics named buffers and latency. Both metrics are in the examples namespace. Both metrics have two dimensions, InstanceID and InstanceType.

Dimensions.name: Dimensions
Dimensions.description: A list of dimensions associated with the metric.

MetricAlarm.name: MetricAlarm
MetricAlarm.description: The MetricAlarm data type represents an alarm. You can use PutMetricAlarm to create or update an alarm.

AlarmArn.name: AlarmArn
AlarmArn.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the alarm.

AlarmConfigurationUpdatedTimestamp.name: AlarmConfigurationUpdatedTimestamp
AlarmConfigurationUpdatedTimestamp.description: The time stamp of the last update to the alarm configuration.

ActionsEnabled.name: ActionsEnabled
ActionsEnabled.description: Indicates whether actions should be executed during any changes to the alarm's state.

OKActions.name: OKActions
OKActions.description: The list of actions to execute when this alarm transitions into an OK state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

AlarmActions.name: AlarmActions
AlarmActions.description: The list of actions to execute when this alarm transitions into an ALARM state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

InsufficientDataActions.name: InsufficientDataActions
InsufficientDataActions.description:
The list of actions to execute when this alarm transitions into an INSUFFICIENT_DATA state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

The current WSDL lists this attribute as UnknownActions.

StateReason.name: StateReason
StateReason.description: A human-readable explanation for the alarm's state.

StateReasonData.name: StateReasonData
StateReasonData.description: An explanation for the alarm's state in machine-readable JSON format

StateUpdatedTimestamp.name: StateUpdatedTimestamp
StateUpdatedTimestamp.description: The time stamp of the last update to the alarm's state.

Statistic.name: Statistic
Statistic.description: The statistic to apply to the alarm's associated metric.

Dimensions.name: Dimensions
Dimensions.description: The list of dimensions associated with the alarm's associated metric.

Period.name: Period
Period.description: The period in seconds over which the statistic is applied.

Unit.name: Unit
Unit.description: The unit of the alarm's associated metric.

EvaluationPeriods.name: EvaluationPeriods
EvaluationPeriods.description: The number of periods over which data is compared to the specified threshold.

Threshold.name: Threshold
Threshold.description: The value against which the specified statistic is compared.

ComparisonOperator.name: ComparisonOperator
ComparisonOperator.description: The arithmetic operation to use when comparing the specified Statistic and Threshold. The specified Statistic value is used as the first operand.

MetricDatum.name: MetricDatum
MetricDatum.description: The MetricDatum data type encapsulates the information sent with PutMetricData to either create a new metric or add new values to be aggregated into an existing metric.

Dimensions.name: Dimensions
Dimensions.description: A list of dimensions associated with the metric. Note, when using the Dimensions value in a query, you need to append .member.N to it (e.g., Dimensions.member.N).

Timestamp.name: Timestamp
Timestamp.description: The time stamp used for the metric in ISO 8601 Universal Coordinated Time (UTC) format. If not specified, the default value is set to the time the metric data was received.

Value.name: Value
Value.description:
The value for the metric.

Although the Value parameter accepts numbers of type Double, Amazon CloudWatch rejects values that are either too small or too large. Values must be in the range of 8.515920e-109 to 1.174271e+108 (Base 10) or 2e-360 to 2e360 (Base 2). In addition, special values (e.g., NaN, +Infinity, -Infinity) are not supported.

StatisticValues.name: StatisticValues
StatisticValues.description: A set of statistical values describing the metric.

AlarmName.name: AlarmName
AlarmName.description: The descriptive name for the alarm. This name must be unique within the user's AWS account

ActionsEnabled.name: ActionsEnabled
ActionsEnabled.description: Indicates whether or not actions should be executed during any changes to the alarm's state.

OKActions.name: OKActions
OKActions.description:
The list of actions to execute when this alarm transitions into an OK state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

Valid Values: arn:aws:automate:region (e.g., us-east-1):ec2:stop | arn:aws:automate:region (e.g., us-east-1):ec2:terminate | arn:aws:automate:region (e.g., us-east-1):ec2:recover

Valid Values (for use with IAM roles): arn:aws:swf:us-east-1:{customer-account}:action/actions/AWS_EC2.InstanceId.Stop/1.0 | arn:aws:swf:us-east-1:{customer-account}:action/actions/AWS_EC2.InstanceId.Terminate/1.0 | arn:aws:swf:us-east-1:{customer-account}:action/actions/AWS_EC2.InstanceId.Reboot/1.0

Note: You must create at least one stop, terminate, or reboot alarm using the Amazon EC2 or CloudWatch console to create the EC2ActionsAccess IAM role for the first time. After this IAM role is created, you can create stop, terminate, or reboot alarms using the CLI.

AlarmActions.name: AlarmActions
AlarmActions.description:
The list of actions to execute when this alarm transitions into an ALARM state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

Valid Values: arn:aws:automate:region (e.g., us-east-1):ec2:stop | arn:aws:automate:region (e.g., us-east-1):ec2:terminate | arn:aws:automate:region (e.g., us-east-1):ec2:recover

Valid Values (for use with IAM roles): arn:aws:swf:us-east-1:{customer-account}:action/actions/AWS_EC2.InstanceId.Stop/1.0 | arn:aws:swf:us-east-1:{customer-account}:action/actions/AWS_EC2.InstanceId.Terminate/1.0 | arn:aws:swf:us-east-1:{customer-account}:action/actions/AWS_EC2.InstanceId.Reboot/1.0

Note: You must create at least one stop, terminate, or reboot alarm using the Amazon EC2 or CloudWatch console to create the EC2ActionsAccess IAM role for the first time. After this IAM role is created, you can create stop, terminate, or reboot alarms using the CLI.

InsufficientDataActions.name: InsufficientDataActions
InsufficientDataActions.description:
The list of actions to execute when this alarm transitions into an INSUFFICIENT_DATA state from any other state. Each action is specified as an Amazon Resource Name (ARN).

Valid Values: arn:aws:automate:region (e.g., us-east-1):ec2:stop | arn:aws:automate:region (e.g., us-east-1):ec2:terminate | arn:aws:automate:region (e.g., us-east-1):ec2:recover

Valid Values (for use with IAM roles): arn:aws:swf:us-east-1:{customer-account}:action/actions/AWS_EC2.InstanceId.Stop/1.0 | arn:aws:swf:us-east-1:{customer-account}:action/actions/AWS_EC2.InstanceId.Terminate/1.0 | arn:aws:swf:us-east-1:{customer-account}:action/actions/AWS_EC2.InstanceId.Reboot/1.0

Note: You must create at least one stop, terminate, or reboot alarm using the Amazon EC2 or CloudWatch console to create the EC2ActionsAccess IAM role for the first time. After this IAM role is created, you can create stop, terminate, or reboot alarms using the CLI.

MetricName.name: MetricName
MetricName.description: The name for the alarm's associated metric.

Namespace.name: Namespace
Namespace.description: The namespace for the alarm's associated metric.

Statistic.name: Statistic
Statistic.description: The statistic to apply to the alarm's associated metric.

Dimensions.name: Dimensions
Dimensions.description: The dimensions for the alarm's associated metric.

Period.name: Period
Period.description: The period in seconds over which the specified statistic is applied.

Unit.name: Unit
Unit.description:
The statistic's unit of measure. For example, the units for the Amazon EC2 NetworkIn metric are Bytes because NetworkIn tracks the number of bytes that an instance receives on all network interfaces. You can also specify a unit when you create a custom metric. Units help provide conceptual meaning to your data. Metric data points that specify a unit of measure, such as Percent, are aggregated separately.

Note: If you specify a unit, you must use a unit that is appropriate for the metric. Otherwise, this can cause an Amazon CloudWatch alarm to get stuck in the INSUFFICIENT DATA state.

EvaluationPeriods.name: EvaluationPeriods
EvaluationPeriods.description: The number of periods over which data is compared to the specified threshold.

Threshold.name: Threshold
Threshold.description: The value against which the specified statistic is compared.

ComparisonOperator.name: ComparisonOperator
ComparisonOperator.description: The arithmetic operation to use when comparing the specified Statistic and Threshold. The specified Statistic value is used as the first operand.

Namespace.name: Namespace
Namespace.description:
The namespace for the metric data.

You cannot specify a namespace that begins with "AWS/". Namespaces that begin with "AWS/" are reserved for other Amazon Web Services products that send metrics to Amazon CloudWatch.

MetricData.name: MetricData
MetricData.description: A list of data describing the metric.

AlarmName.name: AlarmName
AlarmName.description: The descriptive name for the alarm. This name must be unique within the user's AWS account. The maximum length is 255 characters.

StateReason.name: StateReason
StateReason.description: The reason that this alarm is set to this specific state (in human-readable text format)

StateReasonData.name: StateReasonData
StateReasonData.description: The reason that this alarm is set to this specific state (in machine-readable JSON format)

StatisticSet.name: StatisticSet
StatisticSet.description: The StatisticSet data type describes the StatisticValues component of MetricDatum, and represents a set of statistics that describes a specific metric.

SampleCount.name: SampleCount
SampleCount.description: The number of samples used for the statistic set.

Sum.name: Sum
Sum.description: The sum of values for the sample set.

Minimum.name: Minimum
Minimum.description: The minimum value of the sample set.

Maximum.name: Maximum
Maximum.description: The maximum value of the sample set.

title: Amazon CloudWatch
description: Amazon CloudWatch monitors your Amazon Web Services (AWS) resources and the applications you run on AWS in real-time. You can use CloudWatch to collect and track metrics, which are the variables you want to measure for your resources and applications.  CloudWatch alarms send notifications or automatically make changes to the resources you are monitoring based on rules that you define. For example, you can monitor the CPU usage and disk reads and writes of your Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instances and then use this data to determine whether you should launch additional instances to handle increased load. You can also use this data to stop under-used instances to save money.  In addition to monitoring the built-in metrics that come with AWS, you can monitor your own custom metrics. With CloudWatch, you gain system-wide visibility into resource utilization, application performance, and operational health.

methods.description: Deletes all specified alarms. In the event of an error, no alarms are deleted.

DeleteAlarms.name: DeleteAlarms
DeleteAlarms.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url

methods.description: Retrieves history for the specified alarm. Filter alarms by date range or item type. If an alarm name is not specified, Amazon CloudWatch returns histories for all of the owner's alarms. <note> Amazon CloudWatch retains the history of an alarm for two weeks, whether or not you delete the alarm. </note>

DescribeAlarmHistory.name: DescribeAlarmHistory
DescribeAlarmHistory.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url

methods.description: Retrieves alarms with the specified names. If no name is specified, all alarms for the user are returned. Alarms can be retrieved by using only a prefix for the alarm name, the alarm state, or a prefix for any action.

DescribeAlarms.name: DescribeAlarms
DescribeAlarms.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url

methods.description: Retrieves all alarms for a single metric. Specify a statistic, period, or unit to filter the set of alarms further.

DescribeAlarmsForMetric.name: DescribeAlarmsForMetric
DescribeAlarmsForMetric.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url

methods.description: Disables actions for the specified alarms. When an alarm's actions are disabled the alarm's state may change, but none of the alarm's actions will execute.

DisableAlarmActions.name: DisableAlarmActions
DisableAlarmActions.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url

methods.description: Enables actions for the specified alarms.

EnableAlarmActions.name: EnableAlarmActions
EnableAlarmActions.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url

methods.description:
Gets statistics for the specified metric. The maximum number of data points that can be queried is 50,850, whereas the maximum number of data points returned from a single GetMetricStatistics request is 1,440. If you make a request that generates more than 1,440 data points, Amazon CloudWatch returns an error. In such a case, you can alter the request by narrowing the specified time range or increasing the specified period. A period can be as short as one minute (60 seconds) or as long as one day (86,400 seconds). Alternatively, you can make multiple requests across adjacent time ranges. GetMetricStatistics does not return the data in chronological order. Amazon CloudWatch aggregates data points based on the length of the period that you specify. For example, if you request statistics with a one-minute granularity, Amazon CloudWatch aggregates data points with time stamps that fall within the same one-minute period. In such a case, the data points queried can greatly outnumber the data points returned. The following examples show various statistics allowed by the data point query maximum of 50,850 when you call GetMetricStatistics on Amazon EC2 instances with detailed (one-minute) monitoring enabled:
  • Statistics for up to 400 instances for a span of one hour
  • Statistics for up to 35 instances over a span of 24 hours
  • Statistics for up to 2 instances over a span of 2 weeks
For information about the namespace, metric names, and dimensions that other Amazon Web Services products use to send metrics to CloudWatch, go to Amazon CloudWatch Metrics, Namespaces, and Dimensions Reference in the Amazon CloudWatch Developer Guide.

GetMetricStatistics.name: GetMetricStatistics
GetMetricStatistics.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url

methods.description: Returns a list of valid metrics stored for the AWS account owner. Returned metrics can be used with GetMetricStatistics to obtain statistical data for a given metric. Up to 500 results are returned for any one call. To retrieve further results, use returned NextToken values with subsequent ListMetrics operations. If you create a metric with PutMetricData, allow up to fifteen minutes for the metric to appear in calls to ListMetrics. Statistics about the metric, however, are available sooner using GetMetricStatistics.

ListMetrics.name: ListMetrics
ListMetrics.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url

methods.description:
Creates or updates an alarm and associates it with the specified Amazon CloudWatch metric. Optionally, this operation can associate one or more Amazon SNS resources with the alarm. When this operation creates an alarm, the alarm state is immediately set to INSUFFICIENT_DATA. The alarm is evaluated and its StateValue is set appropriately. Any actions associated with the StateValue are then executed. When updating an existing alarm, its StateValue is left unchanged, but it completely overwrites the alarm's previous configuration. If you are using an AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) account to create or modify an alarm, you must have the following Amazon EC2 permissions:
  • ec2:DescribeInstanceStatus and ec2:DescribeInstances for all alarms on Amazon EC2 instance status metrics.
  • ec2:StopInstances for alarms with stop actions.
  • ec2:TerminateInstances for alarms with terminate actions.
  • ec2:DescribeInstanceRecoveryAttribute, and ec2:RecoverInstances for alarms with recover actions.
If you have read/write permissions for Amazon CloudWatch but not for Amazon EC2, you can still create an alarm but the stop or terminate actions won't be performed on the Amazon EC2 instance. However, if you are later granted permission to use the associated Amazon EC2 APIs, the alarm actions you created earlier will be performed. For more information about IAM permissions, see Permissions and Policies in Using IAM. If you are using an IAM role (e.g., an Amazon EC2 instance profile), you cannot stop or terminate the instance using alarm actions. However, you can still see the alarm state and perform any other actions such as Amazon SNS notifications or Auto Scaling policies. If you are using temporary security credentials granted using the AWS Security Token Service (AWS STS), you cannot stop or terminate an Amazon EC2 instance using alarm actions.

PutMetricAlarm.name: PutMetricAlarm
PutMetricAlarm.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url

methods.description: Publishes metric data points to Amazon CloudWatch. Amazon CloudWatch associates the data points with the specified metric. If the specified metric does not exist, Amazon CloudWatch creates the metric. When Amazon CloudWatch creates a metric, it can take up to fifteen minutes for the metric to appear in calls to ListMetrics. Each PutMetricData request is limited to 8 KB in size for HTTP GET requests and is limited to 40 KB in size for HTTP POST requests. Although the Value parameter accepts numbers of type Double, Amazon CloudWatch rejects values that are either too small or too large. Values must be in the range of 8.515920e-109 to 1.174271e+108 (Base 10) or 2e-360 to 2e360 (Base 2). In addition, special values (e.g., NaN, +Infinity, -Infinity) are not supported. Data that is timestamped 24 hours or more in the past may take in excess of 48 hours to become available from submission time using GetMetricStatistics.

PutMetricData.name: PutMetricData
PutMetricData.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url

methods.description: Temporarily sets the state of an alarm for testing purposes. When the updated StateValue differs from the previous value, the action configured for the appropriate state is invoked. For example, if your alarm is configured to send an Amazon SNS message when an alarm is triggered, temporarily changing the alarm's state to ALARM sends an Amazon SNS message. The alarm returns to its actual state (often within seconds). Because the alarm state change happens very quickly, it is typically only visible in the alarm's History tab in the Amazon CloudWatch console or through DescribeAlarmHistory.

SetAlarmState.name: SetAlarmState
SetAlarmState.description: This url parameter exists only to differentiate different operations on the same url
